isis.stitle: AIR CONDITIONING BASIC THEORY, SYSTEM DIAGNOSIS AND SERVICE (with R-134a Refrigerant System) - AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEM SERVICE - REFRIGERANT IDENTIFICATION

svcproc.title: REFRIGERANT IDENTIFICATION

warning.para: Before doing any of the work below, read the SERVICE WARNINGS. Failure to read the Service Warnings and to be aware of the dangers involved when working with refrigerant could lead to serious personal injury.

important.para: Although your service equipment may appear physically different from the equipment shown here, the function of the equipment used to perform each service procedure is basically the same. If you are performing these service procedures using service equipment different from that shown, refer to the manufacturer's instructions supplied with that equipment.

svcproc.para: Before any work is done on an HVAC system the refrigerant must be identified.

figure.caption: Figure 38. Typical Refrigerant Identification Setup Diagram (Location of Low Pressure Service Port Varies with Vehicle)

step1.para: Calibrate the Refrigerant Identifier per the manufacturer's instructions.
Connect the sampling hose to the low pressure service port.
Connect the other end of the sampling hose to the Refrigerant Identifier.
Start the sampling procedure (refer to the manufacturer's instructions).

When the sampling is complete the Refrigerant Identifier will indicate a pass/fail condition, the type of refrigerant, and the percentage of concentration. International recognizes only R12 or R134a in a 98% concentration (these systems must be R134a). Anything else is considered contaminated.
Close the service valve and disconnect the sampling hose.
